3.0    PREVENTION PROGRAM

The ammonia refrigeration system at Hunter Farms has two NAICS Codes; 31151  (Dairy Product ? except frozen manufacturing) and 31152 (ice cream and frozen dessert manufacturing) and is considered a ?Program 3? level prevention program as described in Subpart D of 40 CFR 68 (68.65 through 68.87).  The requirements for the prevention program are equivalent to the provisions of 29 CFR 1910.119(a) through (p), OSHA?s Process Safety Management (PSM) standard.  Hunter Farms is subject to PSM and has developed and implemented a PSM program. Development and implementation of a PSM program fulfills the requirements of the RMP prevention program.  Information for each PSM program element is maintained in three-ring binders and file cabinets in Hunter Farms? PSM Library located in the Main Training Room.  The following summarizes information for each element.

    3.1  Process Safety Information (40 CFR 68.65)  

RMP process safety information requirements include compiling written information concerning process chemicals, process technology, and process equipment.  

Compiled chemical information must address:
? toxicity
? permissible exposure limits
? physical data
? reactivity
? corrosivity
? thermal and chemical stability
? hazardous effects of inadvertent mixing of materials that could foreseeably occur
 
 A material safety data sheet (MSDS) that includes this data may be used to meet this requirement.  Hunter Farms maintains a current MSDS for ammonia in the Process Safety Management Binder, in the PSM Library. 
 
 Written information requirements for process technology includes compiling the following:
? a block flow diagram or simplified process flow diagram
? information on process chemistry
? maximum intended inventory of the EPA-regulated substance
? safe upper and lower limits for such items as temperature, pressure, flows, or composition 
? evaluation of the consequences of deviation
 
 Hunter Farms maintains this information in the Process Safety Management Binder in the PSM Library.
 
 Process equipment information for the facility includes:
? materials of construction
? piping and instrument diagrams (P&IDs)
? electrical classification

? relief system design and design basis
? ventilation system design
? design codes and standards employed
? safety systems 
? material and energy balances for new processes built after June 21, 1999
 
 The P&ID?s, electrical schematics and process equipment information are maintained in the Process Safety Management Binder, in the PSM Library.
 
     3.2  Process Hazard Analysis (40 CFR 68.67)  
 
 An initial Process Hazard Analysis (PHA) was conducted on the refrigeration system in June 1999.  The ?What-If? methodology was used to complete the PHA.  Extensive what-if scenarios were addressed using a brainstorming session.  
 
 During the initial PHA, the following hazards of operating an ammonia refrigeration system were identified:  
 
 - toxic release              - equipment failure
 - plane crash             - loss of cooling, heating, electricity, instrument air
 - overpressurization          - tornado
 - corrosion             - human factor


 In order to prevent / control the catastrophic release of ammonia, the following controls are in place at Hunter Farms:  
 
  - alarms and procedures
  - relief valves            - backup pumps
  - check valves        - manual shutoffs
  - purge system                      - automatic shutoffs
  - interlocks                             - rupture disks

 To assist in mitigating a release, Hunter Farms uses the following systems:  
 
  - fire walls
  - enclosure    
 
 Hunter Farms has access to a 24-hour, off-site local hazardous materials (?Hazmat?) response team. They also have 10 associates who are trained to respond to ammonia releases.
 
 To assist in detecting ammonia releases, Hunter Farms utilizes ammonia detectors, which are located throughout the plant, and are managed by the Maintenance Manager and Maintenance Engineer. 24-hour security guards are trained to perform perimeter monitoring in the event of a release.
 
 
 
 
 Results of the initial PHA were compiled in more detail and are maintained in the PSM library.  Changes required, as a result of the initial PHA, were identified and have been addressed.  Information relating to the schedule for implementation of all changes is maintained in the PSM Library, as well.
 
 Changes, which have been implemented as a result of the initial PHA, include:
? installation of safety relief valves (SRVs) and rupture disks
? installation of windsocks at the facility
? security guards with perimeter monitoring capabilities
 
 The PHA will be updated pursuant to the applicable regulations every 5 years.
 
     3.3  Operating Procedures (40 CFR 68.69)  
 
 Hunter Farms? operating procedures must address the steps for each operating phase, the operating limits, safety and health considerations and safety systems and their functions.  
 
 Specific requirements are as follows:
 
 Steps for each 
 Operating Phase     
 Operating Limits     Safety & Health Considerations     Safety Systems & 
 Their Functions
 Initial startup
 Normal operations
 Temporary operations
 Emergency shutdown
 Emergency operations
 Normal shutdown
 Startup following a turnaround or emergency shutdown
 Lockout/Tagout
 Confined space entry
 Opening process equipment or piping
 Entrance into the facility     Consequences of deviations
 Steps to avoid, correct deviations     Chemical properties and hazards
 Precautions for preventing chemical exposure
 Control measures for exposure
 QC for raw materials and chemical inventory     Address whatever is applicable
 
 Refrigeration system standard operating procedures (SOPs) were developed and are used by Hunter Farms? refrigeration operators.  
 
 There are two sets of SOPs  - one copy is maintained in the PSM library and a second copy is kept in the Maintenance Engineer?s office.
 
 
 
 
 
 3.4  Training (40 CFR 68.71) 
 
 As required under PSM, training requirements for new operators at Hunter Farms include training on operating procedures and must cover health and safety hazards, emergency operations, and safe work practices applicable to the associate?s tasks.  The facility also determines that each operator has received and understood the training and keep a record for each employee with the date of the training and the method used to verify that the employee understood the training.
 
 The format of Hunter Farms? PSM training program was last reviewed and revised by the PSM team in March 2004. 
 
 Training materials include, computer software programs, videos, and existing refrigeration equipment SOPs.  The information is maintained in the PSM Library.   
 Hunter Farms? training program consists of classroom review and hands-on sessions, where the procedures are reviewed ?in the field?.  Each operator participates in discussing the procedures and process safety information, while the facilitator notes any necessary changes and deficiencies.  Verification that the operators understood the material is accomplished through verbal questioning, written tests and hands-on demonstrations.  More detailed training documentation and information is maintained in the PSM Library.  Refresher training is provided at least every three years.
 
     3.5  Mechanical Integrity (40 CFR 68.73)  
 
 As required by the regulations, Hunter Farms implements a mechanical integrity program for pressure vessels and storage tanks, piping systems, relief and vent systems and devices, emergency shutdown systems, controls, and  pumps.  The program includes written procedures, training, inspection and testing, equipment deficiencies, and quality assurance.  
 
 The specific required provisions are as follows:
 
? Written Procedures
 1. establish & implement written procedures to maintain the integrity of process equipment
? Training
 1.  Train process maintenance employees in an overview of the process and its hazards
 2.  Assure the training covers the procedures applicable to safe job performance
? Inspection & Testing
 1.  Inspect and test process equipment
 2.  Use recognized and generally accepted good engineering practices
 3.  Follow a schedule that matches the manufacturer?s recommendations or more frequently if prior operating experience indicates is necessary
 4.  Document each inspection/test with: date, inspector name, equipment id, test or inspection performed, results
? Equipment Deficiencies
 1.  Correct equipment deficiencies before further use of process equipment or whenever necessary to ensure safety 
? Quality Assurance
 1.    Establish a QA program for new construction and equipment, newly installed equipment, maintenance materials, and spare parts and equipment
 
 Hunter Farms follows a Mechanical Integrity program to assure system equipment integrity is maintained.  As part of the program, preventative maintenance of the equipment is scheduled, documented and managed by the Maintenance Engineer. 
 
 More detailed information relating to Hunter Farms? mechanical integrity program can be found in the PSM Library, as well.
 
     3.6  Management of Change (40 CFR 68.75)
 
 The regulatory definition of change includes all modifications to equipment, procedures, raw materials and processing conditions other than ?replacement in kind.?  PSM regulations require changes to be properly managed by identifying and reviewing them prior to implementation of  the change.  Management of change includes the following requirements:
 
 MOC Procedures
 must address:     Employees Affected by 
 the Change Must:     Update Process Safety Information if:     Update Operating Procedures if:
 Technical basis for the change
 Impact on safety  & health
 Modifications to operating procedures
 Necessary time period for the change
 Authorization requirements for proposed change     Be informed of the change before startup
 Trained in the change before startup     A change covered by the MOC procedures results in a change in any PSI required under EPA?s rule (? 67.65)     A change covered by MOC procedures results in a change in any operating procedure required under EPA?s rule (? 67.69)
 
 To assure modifications to the refrigeration system (e.g., equipment, instrumentation, process condition modifications) will be managed in a safe and consistent manner, Hunter Farms has implemented a Management of Change program.  The program requires that certain PSM tasks, (such as updating operating procedures, training applicable personnel, updated piping and instrument diagrams, as well as other process safety information) be completed before the modification takes place.  
 
 Management of Change procedures and documentation are maintained in the PSM Library.
 
     3.7  Pre-Startup Review (40 CFR 68.77)  
 
 Under the applicable regulations, a pre-startup safety review is required for new stationary sources or modified stationary sources when the modification is significant enough to require a change in safety information under the management of change element.  Specific requirements are outlined below.
 
 
 
 Design Specifications     Adequate Procedures     PHA/MOC     Training
 Confirm that new or modified construction and equipment meet design specifications     Ensure that procedures for safety, operating, maintenance, and emergencies are adequate and in place.     Perform a PHA and resolve or implement any recommendations for new process.  
 Meet MOC requirements for modified process.     Confirm that each employee involved in the process has been trained completely.
 
 In conjunction with the Management of Change program, a Pre-Startup Safety Review Checklist is used at Hunter Farms to assure required tasks are completed before start-up of the modified system. The Pre-Startup Review documentation is maintained with the Process Safety Management Binder, in the PSM Library.  
 
         3.8  Compliance Audits (40 CFR 68.79) 
 
 Hunter Farms is required to conduct compliance audits every three (3) years.  The audit must include an evaluation of the design and effectiveness of the process safety management system and a field inspection of the safety and health conditions and practices to verify that systems are effectively implemented.
 
 As required, Hunter Farms undergoes an audit every three (3) years.  The most recent compliance audit performed on Hunter Farms? PSM program was performed in June 2002.  Recommendations made as a result of the audit included updates to the SOPs.  The last two (2) audit reports are kept in the PSM Library.
 
     3.9  Incident Investigation (40 CFR 68.81)  
 
 Incident investigation is the process of identifying the underlying causes of incidents and implementing steps to prevent similar events from occurring.  RMP requires the investigation of each incident, which resulted in, or could reasonably have resulted in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  The specific requirements are as follows:
 
? Initiate an investigation promptly, no later than 48 hours of the incident
? Establish an incident investigation team with at least one team member knowledgeable in the process
? Summarize the investigation in a report, including:
 a.  Date of incident
 b.  Date investigation began
 c.  Description of the incident
 d.  Factors contributing to the incident
e.  Any recommendations
f.   Expected date of completion for recommendations or changes
? Address and resolve the team?s findings and recommendations.  Document resolutions and corrective actions
? Review the report with affected personnel, and contractors where applicable
? Retain the report for five years
? Submit RMP if necessary
 
 Hunter Farms has established incident investigation procedures as part of the PSM program for the ammonia refrigeration system.  These procedures can be found in the PSM Library.  
 
     3.10  Employee Participation (40 CFR 68.83) 
 
 Regulations require for employee participation in the prevention process, via the following: 
? Development of a written plan to implement employee participation
? Consultation with employees regarding conducting and developing PHAs and other elements of process safety management
? Providing access to PHAs and all RMP information to employees
 
 Hunter Farms has implemented an associate participation program consistent with PSM requirements.  Associates indirectly involved with the ammonia refrigeration process are informed of the facility?s PSM program through company newsletters, training sessions and new employee orientation.  Associates directly involved with the process participate in all elements of PSM, previously described.  The employee participation plan was last updated June 2002.
 
     3.11  Hot Work Permit (40 CFR 68.85)  
 
 RMP regulations require that a hot work permit be issued for hot work operations conducted on or near a covered process.  The permit must document that PSM fire prevention and protection requirements have been implemented prior to the beginning of the work.  It also must indicate the authorization date and identify the object on which the hot work is to be performed.  The permit must be kept on file until the hot work is completed.
 
 Hunter Farms? Maintenance Engineer presently manages the Hot Work Permit Program.  Program procedures are maintained with the PSM Library.  The procedures were last reviewed and updated in June 2002.
 
     3.12  Contractors (40 CFR 68.87) 
 
 Specific prevention requirements also apply to contractors performing maintenance or repair, turnaround, major renovation, or specialty work on or adjacent to a covered process.  The following separate requirements apply to the facility owner/operator as well as the contractor:
 
 Owner/Operator Requirements      Contractor Requirements
 Check safety performance regarding safety
 Provide safety and hazards information
 Ensure safe work practices, including emergency response
 Verify that the contractor is fulfilling its obligations under this rule     Ensure employee training in safe work practices
 Ensure employees know process hazards and applicable emergency actions
 Document training
 Ensure employees are following facility safety rules
 Inform owner/operator of hazards
 
 Hunter Farms contractors working near the ammonia refrigeration system are required to review Hunter Farms? Contractor Rules packet, as well as sign-off that they will adhere to the policies and procedures contained in the packet.  Contractors working directly on the refrigeration system obtain additional training.  This documentation is maintained in the PSM Library.  The procedures were last reviewed in June 2002.
 
 Also, in February 1998, Hunter Farms? Corporate Engineering Department began conducting contractor safety audits.  This assures the contractor employees are working in a safe and professional manner, in accordance with Hunter Farms? policies and procedures.

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Background Data

In accordance with Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations Chapter 68 (40 CFR 68) promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA), Hunter Farms Dairy (Hunter Farms) submits this Risk Management Plan (RMP) for operations at their High Point, North Carolina facility.  Hunter Farms operations include the processing of dairy products for public consumption. Hunter Farms has been in operation since 1917 and has been at this facility for over 8 years providing quality dairy products and over 130 jobs to the local community. Dairy production has occurred at this facility for over 55 years.

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy

Hunter Farms is committed to protecting the health of its associates, the surrounding community, and the environment; therefore it is Hunter Farms? policy to maintain compliance with 40 CFR 68 as well as Occupational Safety and Health Organization (OSHA) Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations promulgated as Title 29 of the Code of Federal Regulations Chapter 1910, Section 119 (29 CFR 1910.119), and OSHA?s Hazardous Operations and Emergency Response regulations (29 CFR 1910.120). 

Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances

Hunter Farms is subject to section 112(r) of the Clean Air Act because ammonia, a regulated substance, is present at the facility in amounts greater than 10,000 pounds.  Hunter Farms is required to maintain low temperatures in the dairy processing areas of the facility that are within standards required by the Federal Drug Administration (FDA)  to ensure quality in the delivered products.  Hunter Farms uses anhydrous ammonia (the 112(r) regulated substance) as a refrigerant to maintain 75,900 ft2 within the required range of operating temperatures.  Anhydrous ammonia is a typical refrigerant for dairy processing. Hunter Farms? refrigeration system consisting of receivers, accumulators, compressors, evaporators, condensers, and piping can contain an op

erating capacity of 43,000 pounds of anhydrous ammonia.

Accidental Release Prevention Program

The ammonia refrigeration system is designed and constructed in accordance with ANSI/IIAR 2-1992 Standard for Equipment, Design, And Installation of Ammonia Mechanical Refrigerating Systems.  To prevent and mitigate accidental releases of anhydrous ammonia, Hunter Farms has implemented several precautionary measures.  

Hunter Farms has developed and implemented a PSM program pursuant OSHA regulations and as such, has evaluated the system for the potential of anhydrous ammonia releases.   Some of the controls installed to prevent catastrophic releases of ammonia are process equipment (pressure relief valves, rupture disks, purge system, backup pumps, and manual shutoffs) and automated controls (automatic shut-offs, interlocks and ammonia leak detection system). In addition, Hunter Farms has spent time with the local Fire Department who would respond to potential ammonia releases and the Fire Department has toured the facility to become familiar with the location of the system equipment, valves and emergency shut-offs.

Hunter Farms has developed standard operating procedures (SOPs), that  incorporate safety measures into the procedures. for all associates and contractors that have contact with the ammonia refrigeration system. These safety procedures were developed by refrigeration system operators and are reviewed on an as-needed basis. Process safety information for the refrigeration system is reviewed anytime there is a change in the process or SOP.  Hunter Farms requires associate participation in development of overall safety measures used at the plant by means of company newsletters, total quality management teams and training sessions.  Pursuant to written management of change procedures established by Hunter Farms, any changes to the operating procedures are to be communicated to affected employees.

Hunter Farms understands that maintaining the refrigeration syst

em in good working order is essential to preventing accidental releases; therefore Hunter Farms has implemented a preventative maintenance program.  The preventative maintenance program is scheduled, documented and managed by the Maintenance Engineer and the Maintenance Manager to ensure that regular maintenance occurs on the system. 

To ensure that Hunter Farms? control measures are effective in maintaining the safe operation of the plant, regularly scheduled audits are performed on the ammonia refrigeration system:

? In accordance with the PSM program, Hunter Farms conducts detailed PSM compliance audits every three years that incorporates review of process safety information, process hazard analysis, operating procedures, training programs, system mechanical integrity, management of change, pre-start up review procedures, compliance audit procedures, incident investigation procedures, employee participation programs, hot work permit procedures, and contractor safety procedures.
 
? In addition, Hunter Farms is audited by the parent company?s (Harris Teeter) holding company?s (Ruddick Corporation) Corporate Environmental Manager and Corporate Safety Manager on an annual basis.
 
? Hunter Farms? insurance carrier also conducts independent audits on an annual
      basis.

? The NCDA audits the facility on a quarterly basis.

? The FDA audits the facility on a random basis.
 
 Five-Year Accident History
 
 Over the last five years, Hunter Farms has not experienced an accidental off-site release of anhydrous ammonia from the ammonia refrigeration system.
 
 
 
 Emergency Response Program
 
 Hunter Farms has documented emergency response procedures in two documents entitled Special Situation Manual and Emergency Evacuation Program in order to facilitate response efforts in the event of an on-site or off-site anhydrous ammonia release.  Included in the documents are measures to be taken internally by Hunter Farms as well as measures to be taken by off-site response a

gencies.
 
 Hunter Farms has ten on-site personnel to respond to accidental ammonia releases. Personnel that work on the ammonia system receive initial training and annual update training every three years or as needed reviewing safe work practices.  These associates are also trained in the proper use of respirators and receive an annual fit test and initial pulmonary function test.
 
 To assure that the local governmental response agencies are familiar with Hunter Farms? emergency response procedures, Hunter Farms has met with the local fire department.
 
 To plan for an ammonia release with off-site effects, Hunter Farms includes procedures/equipment to passively mitigate the release, procedures to inform local response agencies, transportation maps for response agencies, evacuation route maps, and procedures for public communication.
 
 In addition to the local response agencies, Hunter Farms has arranged emergency response assistance with a local clean-up contractor.
 
 In the event of an anhydrous ammonia release with off-site effects, the general public will be warned using the following methods:
 
? Broadcast message via the Guilford County Central Dispatch
 
? Police and fire vehicles equipped with public address systems, and
 
? Door-to-door notification of residents (if time permits).
 
 Planned Changes to Improve Safety
 
 As a result of Hunter Farms initial process hazard analyses, several changes were implemented at the facility to improve safety and prevent anhydrous ammonia releases.  These changes included improvements to operating procedures, and preventative maintenance program, increased protection of ammonia equipment (e.g., guarding), increased ammonia safety training, improvements to security and formalizing inspections.
